sample.title: Inside Europe‚Äôs Economic Crises With Christine Lagarde | Leaders with Francine Lacqua
sample.description:
Francine Lacqua speaks to Christine Lagarde about Europe‚Äôs economic travails, populism and how to lead through turbulent times. Lagarde, who served as managing director of the International Monetary Fund before becoming president of the European Central Bank, reflects on her response to the global financial crisis, the Eurozone debt crisis and bailout talks with Greece. 

In a widely varied career, she spent more than two decades practicing corporate law before being recruited as France's trade minister in 2005. She sits down with Lacqua in Frankfurt to reveal how she handles high-pressure situations, complex negotiations and dramatic change.

sample.title: Why One Oil Company Has a Head Start in Venezuela
sample.description:
With President Nicol√°s Maduro deposed, President Donald Trump wants US oil giants to revive Venezuela‚Äôs energy industry. Though it‚Äôs unclear who, if anyone, will take part in his plan, Chevron is already there.

After the US attack on the South American country and its rendition of President Nicol√°s Maduro, Trump said he wants to rebuild the country‚Äôs beleaguered infrastructure. While the oil majors mull his entreaties, Chevron may have a distinct advantage since it‚Äôs been operating in Venezuela for decades.

sample.description:

sample.title: How Close Are We To Robots That Actually Do Chores?
sample.description:
Humanoid robots seem to be going mainstream, appearing on stage with Elon Musk, Jensen Huang and all over CES 2026. But in reality, humanoids are often still tele-operated by humans. And they‚Äôre far from ready for mass deployment in the home, where unpredictabilities like kids and pets also raise the stakes for privacy and safety concerns. Still, companies like 1X in the U.S. and Unitree in China are now selling AI home robots for $20,000 and up. CNBC went to the 2nd annual Humanoid Summit in California and CES to find out if home robots will be stuck in demo mode for years to come.

Chapters:
00:00 Introduction
1:29 Hype vs. reality
5:38 Stuck in demo mode
8:33 China and early adoption

sample.title: Anthropic Vs. OpenAI: How Safety Became The Advantage In AI
sample.description:
Daniela and Dario Amodei left OpenAI five years ago to form Anthropic, a company focused on AI safety and enterprise. Since then, the Claude creator's revenue has grown 10x annually for three straight years, with 85% coming from business customers ‚Äî the inverse of OpenAI's consumer-heavy model. Daniela Amodei, the company's president and co-founder, has emerged as the operational counterweight to her brother Dario's technical vision. CNBC's MacKenzie Sigalos interviews Daniela and other experts, and breaks down how Anthropic quietly rose to the top of the AI race.

Chapters:
00:00 Introduction
2:03 The beginning
4:52 The enterprise bet
9:39 Compute is destiny
13:20 An identity defined by OpenAI
16:18 What could go wrong

Reporting by: MacKenzie Sigalos
Edited by: Erin Black

sample.title: How Far Will U.S. Home Prices Fall?
sample.description:
The CNBC Housing Market Survey asks over 100 real estate agents about local market conditions and buy/seller sentiment. In the final quarter of 2025, real estate professionals saw prices remaining flat or falling in many parts of the country. Most homes sold by respondents stayed on the market for over 3 weeks ‚Äì a signal for buyers who‚Äôve delayed purchases as prices hover near record levels. As a result, a growing cohort of agents are reducing their asking prices for listings ‚Äì or pulling them off the market entirely.

Produced by: Lisa Rizzolo
Reported by: Diana Olick
Editing and Graphics by: Carlos Waters
Senior Managing Producer: Shawn Baldwin
Additional Footage: Getty Images, Heather Dell

sample.title: Powell investigation: Republican opposition grows on Capitol Hill
sample.description: Republican protests are growing louder on Capitol Hill as the Trump administration's Department of Justice pursues a criminal investigation into Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. CNBC's Emily Wilkins has the details.

sample.title: How tax-efficient investing could boost your portfolio returns in 2026 and beyond
sample.description:
Retail investors may already be preparing for the start of the 2026 tax filing season, which the IRS announced will begin on Jan. 26.

Tax changes in 2026 include increases in amounts you can contribute to tax-advantaged accounts such as a 401(k) or IRA. Using tax-efficient strategies for 2026 can boost portfolio returns, and the type of accounts you use for various investments is a key strategy to consider. CNBC's Sharon Epperson explains.

sample.title: Trump did not direct DOJ to investigate Powell, says White House
sample.description:
White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said President Donald Trump did not direct Justice Department officials to investigate Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell.
 
The ‚ÄåJustice Department's threat of indictment escalates the president's long-running pressure campaign against the central bank. Powell called the move a "pretext" to win influence over interest rates.

Will Donald Trump intervene following mass protests in Iran? | Global News Podcast
sample.description:
Iran has warned Donald Trump it's prepared to teach him an "unforgettable lesson". It's after the US president warned he was considering "very strong options" after the state's crackdown on anti-government protests.
 
What started as demonstrations over the dire economic situation has now grown into a mass movement. But what action will America take, and why?
 
BBC's international editor Jeremy Bowen has the background.
 
Subscribe to the Global News Podcast wherever you get your podcasts or find more episodes here: https://bbc.in/GlobalNewsPodcast
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#Iran #US #BBCNews
